thread.title: Report: Obama seriously considering sidestepping Congress, expanding background checks
thread.title_full: Report: Obama seriously considering sidestepping Congress, expanding background checks

author: Andrew Theen | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Report: Obama seriously considering sidestepping Congress, expanding background checks
text:
Comments 
President Obama is looking at expanding background checks for gun buyers who purchase their firearms from high-volume dealers, according to the Washington Post. 
Obama is considering an executive order, according to the report, that would allow him to bypass the Republican-controlled Congress. 
The news came as the president arrived in Roseburg on Friday to visit with victims from last week's deadly shooting on Umpqua Community College's campus. Hundreds of protesters were on the scene to demonstrate against Obama's visit. 
According to the Post, Obama is considering a rule change that would apply new background check requirements to gun dealers that exceed a certain threshold of sales each year. 
The Obama Administration first drafted the plan in late 2013, nearly a year after the Sandy Hook massacre and in the months after the failed attempt to pass stricter gun regulations in the spring of 2013. The expanded background check plan, as of 2013, would have applied to dealers that sold at least 50 weapons a year. 
Here's what the Post said about the ongoing controversy: In the wake of last week's tragedy, Obama said he had asked his team "to scrub what kinds of authorities do we have to enforce the laws that we have in place more effectively to keep guns out of the hands of criminals." "We are hopeful we can find a way to do this," said one senior administration official, who noted that lawyers were still working through details to ensure that the rule could pass legal muster. "It's a lot more clear today than it was a year ago how to work this out." 
-- Andrew Theen
